Topic.Title: Goldman just said S&P would plunge.

Message.Msg: Sorry pal... That's why I win on all of these. The market cannot stay irrational longer than I can stay solvent. Ask Sybs. He saw me ride through a 50% gain for 9 months on CMG and I didn't come close to blinking. I don't short stocks (actually, I use a short replacement strategy) where the odds not stacked massively in my favor for an asymmetric return. And, I don't bite more than I can chew for a LONG time. 1) AWS -- Google Cloud and Rackspace OpenStack offerings will provide more competition, require continuous technology infrastructure spend and declining margins. Google is clearly opening a front here and the RackSpace/HPQ OpenStack play is basically going to make this even more competitive moving forward. 2) 3P sales... Looks like eBay is having a bit of a rennaisance. In fact, now getting more traction with traditional retailer storefronts (who are aligned AGAINST AMZN), which will shift the consumer mindset more to looking at eBay as well as AMZN for internet purchases, particularly in the coming holiday season. Plus, eBay has MORE CASH and BETTER cash flow (which it can deploy to build/rent/acquire/partner more local operations WHEN asset values reset to reality). And eBay owns that payment thingy... And, eBay's EV is half of AMZN... 3) AMZN sales... The biggest difference between shorts and longs. Longs believe that AMZN getting product to people more quickly will somehow be game changing for sales. Shorts think collecting taxes on high value density/high ticket items will adversely affect sales growth. Time will tell. Of course, analysts could have gotten at these on the last call by asking about relative sales intensity (AMZN share of retail total on ECG total) in areas where tax is collected versus uncollected, but chose not to... And, they could have gotten a sense of how much people value faster delivery by getting at the percent of shipments choosing to pay for 1 day, 2 day versus regular ground. My wife and I buy plenty of stuff from Amazon. It is rarely time sensitive. We almost always go with free ground. Further, many categories of product tend to be more spontaneous/impulse purchases in the physical world and AMZN's build out just isn't going to make a dent there. We're still shopping at Dominick's (Safeway), Costco and Target for most things we need and we do it on the way home from work. The vision of laying waste to all retail is BS. That will become clear soon enough. I hope AMZN finds itself in a cash squeeze (with Google, Rackspace, Apple, WalMart and Best Buy all coming after it hard, each targeting a different area to beat AMZN on price) in the coming year. It would be poetic justice to see it need to raise cash in a challenging environment after all the retailers it put out of business based upon a tax subsidy that it is now trying to eliminate. Typical big company BS to write the rules to its advantage.

Topic.Title: Goldman just said S&P would plunge.

Message.Msg: Yes, I am. Those products generally require a contractor service/installation network like Home Depot has developed. HD has attractive unit economics itself (purchasing scale, inv turns, etc) so AMZN has no major cost advantage. When people start segmenting the opportunity critically, they'll see the hype is way overblown: inherently offline purchases (gas, dining, etc), already migrated online and dominated by others (travel), spontaneous/impulsive real time purchases (most food and groceries), those requiring extensive local service networks (large appliances or even paint...). The bottom line is that AMZN's model is well suited to certain categories of goods with relatively high value density that are not perishable and don't require on the ground service. It's much smaller than is being hyped... And, it is (directionally at the very least) losing an artificial subsidy moving forward...

Message.Title: Misek of Jefferies loved RIMM in 2007
Message.Msg: RIM: Canaccord Adams Analyst Finds Concerns Overdone November 19, 2007 | 1 comment | about: RIMM Shares of Research In Motion Ltd. (RIMM) have fallen roughly 22% in the past two weeks. Weakness in the financial services sector and fears that this will hurt BlackBerry sales are taking some of the blame. But Canaccord Adams analyst Peter Misek thinks the concerns are overdone and the lower share price represents a buying opportunity. He says RIM’s exposure to the financial services sector is only through 10% to 15% of its subscriber base, much lower than a year or two ago. Mr. Misek also looked back to the last slowdown in financial services between 2000 and July 2002 when Wall Street firms reduced jobs by roughly 7%, or just over 25,000 people. If the same thing were to occur today, it would be equivalent to just one day of net subscriber additions for RIM, he told clients in a note. RIM saw consumer segment subscriber growth of nearly 50% last quarter, a trend Mr. Misek thinks will continue this quarter and one that signals its diversification. The analyst also expects RIM’s net subscriber additions will be strong this quarter due to demand in Europe and Latin America, as well as with Verizon (VZ) and AT&T (T) in the U.S. He forecasts shipments of 4.1 million BlackBerrys and 1.8 million net subscriber additions for the quarter, versus the consensus at 3.7 million and 1.7 million, respectively. Mr. Misek maintained his “buy” recommendation and US$160 price target on RIM shares.

Message.Title: Uh, oh. Maybe not hold this weekend.
Message.Msg: I hate it when the VIX gets this low. You know something big (and awful) is going to happen. From Zerohedge: VIX is nothing more than the market's implied 'factor' that makes the supply-demand of options prices fit with model-based parameters. In simple terms it measures the market's expectations for volatility (up or down moves - not just down) going forward. Empirically it has a relationship with realized volatility - how much the market actually moved up or down relative to what VIX expected - and professionals will use various 'scalping' techniques to lock in day-to-day gains from the difference between the market's actual movement and what options prices expected. To wit: the current expectations of central bank action, just as it did in 11/2011 (global CB action) and 1/2012 (LTRO1), has caused a slow steady leak higher in stocks which crushes realized volatility - currently at record lows. This in turn drags implied vol lower as the 'scalpers' sell vol to capture the difference. With September 'events' around the corner, we suspect there are only a few more days before realized vol picks up and implicitly implied vol momentum scalpers are squeezed out again (and despite a low absolute VIX, the market IS pricing for a pick-up in risk).

Topic.Title: The P/E and PEG is insane

Message.Msg: AMZN generated on the order of $100MM in free cash flow in the past 12 months. It generated $3B in operating cash flow, assuming you want to ignore ALL investments and buybacks... That's 36X operating cash flow in a macro environment at risk for significant shock. That is patently insane. By compromising its cash position and it has made itself vulnerable in the event of a macro shock. Given its working capital model, a sales slowdown could prove disastrous. Somehow, I suspect those who've been planning appropriately for the macro shock aren't go to go easy on AMZN...

Message.Title: Is this true or a pump
Message.Msg: Forget Apple, Forget Facebook: Here's The One Company That Actually Terrifies Google Execs By Nicholas Carlson | Business Insider – Wed, Aug 15, 2012 It's very easy to get caught up in the Android versus iPhone duel and Google's recruiting battles with its newly-public Silicon Valley neighbor, Facebook. But neither one of those companies worry Google executives as much as another that is actively taking money out of their pockets. This company is from Washington, but no, it's not Microsoft. Google's real rival, and real competition to watch over the next few years is Amazon. Google is a search company, but the searches that it actually makes money from are the searches people do before they are about to buy something online. These commercial searches make up about 20 percent of total Google searches. Those searches are where the ads are. What Googlers worry about in private is a growing trend among consumers to skip Google altogether, and to just go ahead and search for the product they would like to buy on Amazon.com, or, on mobile in an Amazon app. There's data to prove this trend is real. According to ComScore, Amazon search queries are up 73 percent in the last year. But it makes intuitive sense doesn't it? Why go through these steps … •Google search "rubber galoshes," •Analyze some text links, •Click on one to go to a product page on some e-commerce store, •Click to add the item to your cart, •Input your credit card, •Input your address, … when you can just … •Search amazon for "rubber galoshes," •Click one button to buy the product with your usual credit card and have it shipped to your normal address. On mobile, where Amazon has its own app and Google is just a search bar for a smaller-screened browser, the equation tips further in Amazon's balance. The scenario gets even scarier for Google if Kindle phones and Kindle tablets gain ubiquity. If you have a Kindle phone, which comes with free movies and books because you have an Amazon Prime account, which also gives you free shipping, why in the WORLD would you ever search to buy something through anything but Amazon? You wouldn't. That's why Amazon is practically giving its hardware away. It's also why Amazon scares Google more than anything Facebook or Apple are up to.

Topic.Title: The P/E and PEG is insane

Message.Msg: Just another part of the framing scam. Multiples used to mean TTM because that was FACT. Companies got rewarded for what they delivered in actual profit growth, not what some starry eyed analyst dreams might happen in 2015. Last I checked, virtually no one saw the financial crisis happening in 2008 at the start of 2007. But, these analyst are suggesting to buy a stock trading at 36X EBITDA because gross margins are expanding and they hope it might make more money in 2015? This one is going to be epic. CMG was a few billion hit. This ponzi is BIG. The losses for those that don't get out before we fall into recession or suffer from a shock will be huge and material. And, it will all have been knowable with robust due diligence (if you have billions invested here, you better be damned sure that AMZN's share and profitability are just as high where it does collect taxes -- that its growth and profitability will not fall off when it starts collecting everywhere... hoping is flat out negligent in this macro climate with these multiples).
